content.heading: HTML Image Maps
paragraphs: HTML image maps allow you to create clickable regions on an image, directing users to different destinations based on the area clicked.

content.heading: Image Maps
paragraphs: The <map> element defines an image map, and the clickable areas within it are specified using one or more <area> elements.

content.heading: How It Works
paragraphs: To use an image map, you need an image with a 'usemap' attribute and a <map> element containing clickable <area> regions. The coordinates of each <area> define its clickable space.

content.heading: The Image
paragraphs: Insert the image with the tag and connect it to a map using the 'usemap' attribute.

content.heading: Creating the Map
paragraphs: Use the <map> element and give it a name that matches the 'usemap' reference in the image.

content.heading: Clickable Areas
paragraphs: Each clickable region is defined using the <area> element. You must specify the shape and coordinates of the region.

content.heading: Example: Circular Area
paragraphs: Defines a circular clickable region using the center point and radius.

content.heading: Example: Polygon Area
paragraphs: Defines a polygonal clickable region with a list of x,y coordinate pairs.

content.heading: Using JavaScript with Maps
paragraphs: You can add interactivity to image maps by attaching JavaScript functions to area elements using the onclick attribute.

content.heading: Summary
paragraphs: Use with the 'usemap' attribute to reference a map.
Define the map using <map> and assign it a name.
Specify clickable regions inside the map with <area> and provide shape and coordinates.
